pulls.title: Requirements
pulls.author: felixlinker
pulls.body:
I synthesized a list of requirements from the following two drafts:

- https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-haberman-digital-emblem-ps-03
- https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-linker-digital-emblem-02

I did not include all requirements from draft-haberman-digital-emblem-ps-03 as some seem redundant/empty. Please let me know if you would like these requirements to be included. I am not certain of all text and will add some comments to the PR. Would be great to receive some input here!

My plan for the structure of the document is to add use cases to either as part of the initial scope or as other and then list at each requirement which use case has it. I find this the clearest to understand the problem space! Open to feedback here to.

For now, I put all requirements into the "other" part because there are no use cases in the initial scope section. As soon as we add use cases for the initial scope, we can move requirements up one by one.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
Felix,
As you didn't post to the list for comment, I would avoid removing
requirements. Even after posting to the list, it is typical to wait several
weeks.

Have you tried reaching out one-on-one to the source of these requirements
to have short call with them?
thanks,
-rohan

On Mon, Jun 23, 2025, 00:27 Felix Linker ***@***.***> wrote:

> ***@***.**** commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In draft-linker-diem-requirements.md
> <https://github.com/felixlinker/diem-requirements/pull/1#discussion_r2160907492>
> :
>
> > +#### Geographic
> +
> +An emblem MUST be restrictable by geographic scope.
> +
> +Use cases that have this requirement:
>
> Removed this requirement as I did not get any input.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/felixlinker/diem-requirements/pull/1#discussion_r2160907492>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AADSQPWSV4DQ3DZXT4LTEBL3E6T6PAVCNFSM6AAAAAB7B2PDE2VHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43YUDVNRWFEZLROVSXG5CSMV3GSZLXHMZDSNBYHE3DKMJVGA>
> .
> You are receiving this because you commented.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body:
> Felix,
> As you didn't post to the list for comment, I would avoid removing
> requirements. Even after posting to the list, it is typical to wait several
> weeks.
>
> Have you tried reaching out one-on-one to the source of these requirements
> to have short call with them?
> thanks,
> -rohan

I did not try to schedule a call, but I did share the PRs with other active participants, inviting them to provide feedback. That includes the source of these requirements (I presume you mean Bill an Brian).

I find both these requirements a bit too strong. Either a client knows how to parse an emblem or they don't. In case a client knows how to parse it, clients are free to provide references to visual representations or laws, but why enforce the encoding of these? Seems to make standards overly bloaty.
This requirement is not entirely clear to me. I took it from the draft-haberman-digital-emblem-ps-03. Should the issuer or an authorizating party be able to do so? Or both?

I find this requirement too open. I would presume that individual use cases have specific types of additional, relevant information, and we should be able to spell out what information that is. This is basically asking for a free text field otherwise (but maybe that's desired). I think the requirement could benefit from specificity.
How do the requirements in https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-haberman-digital-emblem-ps-03.html#name-notional-requirements-for-d mesh with this list?

MUST provide a clearly detectable and unambiguous marking mappable to enable verification,
> I did not understand this requirement.

MUST be machine-readable to enable automated verification,
> I found this reuqirement redundant and clear from context.

MUST be capable of carrying a visual representation of the physical emblem it represents,
> Included as "Visual"

MUST carry an unambiguous indication of the international law or laws conferring protection upon the entity marked with the emblem,
> Included as "Law Carrying"

MUST be possible to associate with a range or specific quantity of persons or items,
> Included as "Physical Binding" (and sub-requirements)

MUST be possible to associate with online services (e.g., websites, email servers, databases),
MUST be possible to associate with data in transit or at rest,
MUST be possible to associate with network-addressable equipment (e.g., routers, servers, laptops, IoT devices),
> I found these requirements better to be addressed by the scope and use cases and not put as requirements. In the initial scope, we already say that bearers will be identified by FQDN, for example.

MUST be possible to associate with a physical object (e.g., building, vehicle, container),
> Included as "Physical Binding"

MUST be possible to associate with a person or group of people
> Included as "Identity Binding"
I'm not sure what this means.  Could you expound and/or provide an example?
I would like to better understand the motivation behind this requirement.  Could you provide a practical example?

Yes, the point is that there cannot be, e.g., a registry or dedicated set of authorizers. For example, one could consider root CAs as such a dedicated set of authorizers in the context of the Web PKI. (It's a bit more nuanced, because iirc are chosen by browser vendors, i.e., the spec doesn't mandate a dedicated set of authorizers, but I hope the example still helps.) This is a requirement for emblems under IHL, because displaying them (most often) requires authorization from states, but states themselves must not require authorization to do so.

Maybe "anyone" is a bit too strict, though. I don't need my mother to authorize emblem usage :)

I hope the first part of the requirement is clear, namely, that emblems and authorizations must carry the identity of the signer. This is very typical for certificate-style designs, but not a given.

The second part is about being able to hold illicit display of digital emblems accountable. If someone illegitamtely displays an emblem (which, for the most part, can only be determined after the fact), we must be able to hold that display accountable. Using digital signatures already goes a long way to realize this requirement!

One could make the requirement stronger and require accountability directly, though, it may be unclear what this means.

Thanks. I think I understand you to mean that validators/consumers can authorize who they want (i.e., their equivalent of a set of root CAs)?  Does this also mean that authorized issuers can also extend that authorization to whom they want?  I'm not opposed to these, but if this is what you mean, then let's spell it out that way with something like the following:

> There is no global registry of authorized issuers.  Issuers are authorized independently by validators and other issuers.
Okay, that makes sense - thanks!

I don't think that's entirely what I mean, but it seems related.

Basically, I want to require that there is no one who tells someone who an auhtorizing party is (by the spec). For example, a draft could say: "There is a IANA registry for DIEM-authorizing parties and a DIEM designated experts group decides who is in that registry and validators must only accept emblems authorized by one of these issuers." This would be a straightforward violation of that requirement.

If I decide tomorrow that I want to authorize someone to display digital emblems, I should be able to do that with reaonsable effort. I should not be required to ask for permission from a fixed authority, or I should not be required to be in some registry or similar.

```suggestion
```

I suggest removing these requirements. For certain use cases, such functionality could be useful, but I think it would be better integrated in validator clients and need not be realized by the IETF standard.

I made up my mind. I think this requirement should be removed or replaced with more specific version. One could standardize a freetext field (or even binary), for example. Without further input why this is required and for what use case, I would remove it.
Removed this requirement as I did not get any input.

pulls.title: Use case of emblems under IHL
pulls.author: felixlinker
pulls.body: This PR adds the use case of emblems under IHL. It references requirements as introduced in #1 (as of f137e35d2b3ac33c630c861827667a804dd9f893).

comments.body: I think this heading might be confusing since it is immediately under use cases for initial scope. That the use cases are related to IHL does not make them initial scope. Most of the pure-digital bearer use cases for IHL are in scope, but not *because* they are IHL.

This makes no mention that hospitals and their resources are protected whether they display one of RedC* emblems or not. A hospital of a medical NGO that does not use those symbols but instead uses for example their own logo is still protected under IHL.
But the heading does not say we include them because they are IHL? It just says that digital emblems under IHL are a use case under the intial scope.
That is true. It is _slightly_ hinted towards when saying "which inform other parties" (not "which give"!). Could go into more detail here.

pulls.title: draft-haberman-digital-emblem-ps-03 use cases
pulls.author: felixlinker
pulls.body:
This pull requests adds use cases from the draft https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-haberman-digital-emblem-ps-03 to the document.

I did not include IHL emblems as they are covered by #2. I also did not include UN and WHO use cases as they were underspecified. I hope I reflect the use cases faithfully. Please let me know if not!

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: This is also missing the Press usage case and the UNESCO use case.

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body:
UNESCO is covered by #2.

Press will be covered by Michaela Shapiro. I invited her to contribute text as she knows far more about the problem.

```suggestion
The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), and the Basel Convention require that certain, dangerous materials are marked during shipment.
```
Could we soften this to say: "The focus of the initial DIEM efforts does not include the following use cases."
To me, both sentences say the exact same thing, so I don't mind. But could you explain how they differ? (If they were the same to you, I guess you wouldn't propose the change.)
